Is there any code I can run right now to test drive this idea, or any advice on the modifications needed to get started? It seems like it would be perfect for rapidly prototyping, and I'd like an excuse to dig into my next project this weekend.

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Update template/demo with filtering, paging and sorting features." (#1014)

Issues.Title: [Bind] Support for bool?
Issues.Body:
Implements #1007 and based on the work of @Daddoon in #630
Make it possible to bind to a nullable bool (bool?), often used for a 3 state checkbox. 
- Null : any
- True : True
- False : False

The state of the checkbox is not yet touched and therefore "null", but if it is touched it's true or false which should bind to the value.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[Bind] Support for bool?" (#1012)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "minify blazor.js" (#1011)

Issues.Title: Service Side vs Client Side
Issues.Body:
First of all, what you guys(the Blazor **and** the Mono team) are doing is amazing, keep it up!

I do believe we should weigh out the pro's vs cons on short- and long term. Since we can use .NET Core on the server side now -which is proven to be performant and stable- we don't have to worry about the bugs, feature requests and release pace of the Mono team. Therefore we might want to consider to first focus on the server side and once Mono to .WASM is stable enough we should take on the client-side, since we can focus on Blazor itself and be less dependent on the release pace of Mono. 

As a final note, there are use cases for both implementations but let's use something that is stable and move Blazor itself forward without having to worry about some core dependencies.

Additional:
Is there a template we can play with for the Server Side?
Any idea when the 'experimental' phase could be over? 2-3 months, a year, two years?

Based on the [stand-up episode](https://youtu.be/CWuIz9khK-o?list=PL1rZQsJPBU2StolNg0aqvQswETPcYnNKL&t=3134).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Service Side vs Client Side" (#1006)

Issues.Title: [Bind] Nullable Bool unsupported (bool?)
Issues.Body:
A lot of work has been done for the bind method, let's add the one for nullable bool. `bool?`

Current error:
Uncaught (in promise) Error: System.ArgumentException: 'bind' does not accept values of type System.Nullable`1[[System.Boolean, mscorlib, Version=2.0.5.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e]]. To read and write this value type, wrap it in a property of type string with suitable getters and setters.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Bind] Nullable Bool unsupported (bool?)" (#1007)

Issues.Title: Blazor running c# on the server-side and in Electron - A Ramble
Issues.Body:
When I saw the demo of the c# code running on the server-side and sending the diff to the client

I thought my head would explode with all the things this would simplify for my team

We are a bespoke software company. We do not have a product, we write system for clients ranging from WinForms systems that track 1,000,000 tyres leaving a warehouse each year, to websites that quote business insurance to insurance brokers, to system for managing large plastic bag manufacturers and giant moulding factories and many more things. 

**What all these projects have in common are: -**

- 	relatively small user bases, between 25 to maybe 500 users in total per application, not all of which use the system at the same time
- 	Complicated and often changeable data collection and validation requirements
- 	interaction with a SQL database, usually in azure. 
- 	user identity and roles.
- 	User location within the UK so no more 500 miles from Cardiff or London data centres
- 	A web based application of some sort, even if it is only a part of a larger collection of applications

So potential down sides mentioned by Steve, Latency, Server Workload etc. would not be a problem for us. 

**What we could gain**

- Objects never leave server, so are kept up to date in one place and do not need to be passed around
- Direct access to database 
- Direct access to active directory 
- 	Business logic, form validation etc all in one place, no need to part validate on the client and then revalidate on the server.
- 	single upgrade point, no worrying about cached copies. 
- 	full .net
- 	load speed
- 	changes to business logic not needing to be sent to the client, or handled via an api.
- 	No sensitive data needed on the client
- 	No business logic on the client

While I appreciate that for huge large scale global applications hosting the application on the server using your own compute is a negative, but for relatively small user base, enterprise applications this seems to me like having my cake and getting to eat it too. 

If it was possible I would like to see all three options built out, however my thoughts on importance have changed. 

I started out seeing Blazor as a way I could replace angular or react etc. with a .net process which was really cool.

But the idea of having the option of running on the server or running like an installed application within electron allowing a multi-platform solution with access to local resources for the client compute option, these seem more compelling propositions than just removing the pain of having to code JavaScript (or even TypeScript) but still being limited by the browser manufacturers choices.

I apologies if this turned into a bit of a ramble, but I just wanted to let you guys know just how excited this project has got me and for a programmer of 30+ years that is quite an achievement.

Thanks for all your hard work on this, just so you know I will be absolutely gutted if this does not get the go ahead in all 3 forms, **but can I have the server-side version first please.**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Blazor running c# on the server-side and in Electron - A Ramble " (#1004)

Issues.Title: [Interop] Pass Action<T> / Delegate in object
Issues.Body:
I'm currently porting the Web Notifications API from JavaScript to Blazor see: [Blazor.Notifications](https://github.com/vertonghenb/Blazor.Notifications). 

To do so I'm passing an object via interop and registering the `onClick` functions via the new features of the interop introduced in 0.4.0 to callback to C# functions. However it would be nice if we could pass `Action<UIMouseEventArgs>` in the object directly via interop to JavaScript.

Is this even possible?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Interop] Pass Action<T> / Delegate in object" (#1005)

Issues.Title: State is not being updated on button click
Issues.Body:
1: Download the source from this branch https://github.com/mrpmorris/blazor-fluxor/tree/bug/StateNotChanging

2: Set this project as your startup project MiddlwareSample.Server (in the 04-MiddlewareSample solution folder)

3: Run it

4: Now click either of the buttons. Both should update their own counter, but neither do. (If it works then refresh the page and try again to break it).

If you get rid of the `@inherits` line from `index.cshtml` then the counter example with in-view state works (the bottom button) but then the global-state change detection cannot work.

This worked in 0.30
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "State is not being updated on button click" (#1001)

Issues.Title: Blazor Component generated class names should avoid potential clashes with member names
Issues.Body:
In other MS frameworks (e.g. Razor Pages, Web Pages), generated view class names have a prefix or suffix added that minimises the chances of a member being declared with the same name as the generated class e.g. `Pages_Product`. A Blazor component named Product.cshtml results in a class named "Product". 

I have been caught out a few times now adding a member name that matches the generated class name, whereas this is not something I need to think about with other frameworks. Can the generated class name be prefixed with `Blazor_` or similar?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Blazor Component generated class names should avoid potential clashes with member names" (#994)

Issues.Title: Custom index.html for Blazor
Issues.Body:
Is there any way to use a custom "index.html"? If not, is it on the road-map?

Because I think it would be great because adding a custom index.html for your project could open the possibility to:

- Target a DOM element for Blazor code, like Angular, React... So part of the page could be static HTML and some DIV would be replaced with the rendered application. (I think it require some change in Blazor to accept the Id of the element)
- Customizable "Loading page", instead of the currently used simple "Loading..." message. (It should work out of the box).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Custom index.html for Blazor" (#995)

Issues.Title: Quotation marks in bind, onclick, etc. - bug or feature?
Issues.Body:
In `cshtml` file we can write something like this:
```html
<input bind="@MyProperty" />
<button onclick="@MyClickHandler">Click Me</button>
```
or exactly the same, but without quotation marks
```html
<input bind=@MyProperty />
<button onclick=@MyClickHandler>Click Me</button>
```
Is it bug or undocumented feature? It confuses some people - read comments in #127
I have browsed documentation and there is only one place in "Introduction" where Razor expression is used without quotation marks:
```html
<button onclick=@OnOK>OK</button>
```
In all other places quotation marks are used.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Quotation marks in bind, onclick, etc. - bug or feature?" (#997)

Issues.Title: VS shouldn't offer to scaffold MVC controllers inside Blazor client apps
Issues.Body:
Currently with Blazor 0.4 when you try to add a new Controller VS 2017 shows the dialog below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7632824/41413153-8194b6d8-6fe2-11e8-98f6-5928dada073f.png)

However no mater what you choose it will hang VS for minutes, or indefinitely. So most of the times I have to kill the process. But it doesn't mater VS was able to finish the setup or not because you wont be able to build that project again... 

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error		rzc generate exited with code 1.	BlazorTest	C:\Users\imre\.nuget\packages\microsoft.aspnetcore.blazor.build\0.4.0\targets\RazorCompilation.targets	184
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "VS shouldn't offer to scaffold MVC controllers inside Blazor client apps" (#996)

Issues.Title: 'Router' cannot find any component with a route for '/' with 0.4.0
Issues.Body:
Hi,
I'm trying to upgrade my [Blazor demo application](https://github.com/gpeipman/BlazorDemo) to 0.4.0. It uses code-behind for Blazor pages and it works fine with 0.3.0. When trying to run it on 0.4.0 I get the following error to browser console: Error: System.InvalidOperationException: 'Router' cannot find any component with a route for '/'.

I added full stack trace shown in browser as formatting got lost in GitHub textbox: 
[blazor-exception-trace.txt](https://github.com/aspnet/Blazor/files/2100963/blazor-exception-trace.txt)

Are there any additional steps for upgrading besides ones given at blog post here: https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/webdev/2018/06/07/blazor-0-4-0-experimental-release-now-available/ ?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "'Router' cannot find any component with a route for '/' with 0.4.0" (#992)

Issues.Title: Add TagAttribute for component properties
Issues.Body:
While the ParameterAttribute allows a property to be used as a component attribute (ex. where MyParameter is [Parameter], thus `<MyCustomComponent MyParameter=...>`), the TagAttribute allows a property to be used as a component's child tag. Ex. where Template is [Tag]:

```
    <MyCustomComponent>  
        <Template>  
            ...
        </Template>  
    </MyCustomComponent>  
```

This is subtly suggested in #404. A possible side-effect is that a property can be both [Parameter] and [Tag], allowing it to be used as a component attribute or child tag. Either way, the idea is that the contents, in-line or declarative, are assigned to the property.

In a declaration/usage, it should be an error to use the same [Parameter][Tag] property as both attribute and tag. Either one but not both, so that the ff. is an error:

```
    <MyCustomComponent MyParameterTag=...>  
        <MyParameterTag>  
            ...
        </MyParameterTag>  
    </MyCustomComponent>  
```

Because MyParameterTag is used as both parameter and tag in this declaration, there is no way to know which content to keep. Should it be a design-time or compile-time error?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add TagAttribute for component properties" (#987)

Issues.Title: Target Netstandard2.0 in Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server package
Issues.Body:
Currently the [Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server](https://dotnet.myget.org/feed/blazor-dev/package/nuget/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server) package targets `netcoreapp2.0`.
This prevents aspnetcore webapps targeting the full framework from using it to server blazor client apps.

Is there a specific reason behind this decision?

A proposed change would be to change the targetframework to `netstandard2.0`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Target Netstandard2.0 in Microsoft.AspNetCore.Blazor.Server package" (#986)

Issues.Title: Form with @onsubmit sends POST to server
Issues.Body:
This started with Blazor 0.4.

On my form I have a "@onsubmit" handler. When I click on the button with type="submit" the event is not raised but a classic POST is sent to the server.

[My File](https://github.com/RemiBou/Toss.Blazor/blob/master/Toss/Toss.Client/Shared/LoginClassic.cshtml)

And then i get an error "The SPA default page middleware could not return the default page ..." it might be connected to issue #951 or #803
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Form with @onsubmit sends POST to server" (#988)
